name: Oriental Whipsnake
description: It has a long, whip-like body and a slender, pointed head. With large eyes and horizontal pupils, it accurately judges distances. A distinctive feature is its elongated snout. Coloration can be bright green, olive, or gray-green.
food_note: Lizards, frogs, and other small vertebrates
image_alt: Oriental whipsnake, photo: Tereza Mrhálková, Prague Zoo
proportions: Body length up to 150 cm; tail length up to 50 cm; average weight 300 g
attractions: Like all whipsnakes, it can perfectly weave through branches, virtually disappearing among climbing plants and leaves. It spends most of its time in tree canopies or bushes but often hunts on the ground. Active during the day, it has venomous fangs at the back of its jaws, gripping prey until the venom takes effect.
breeding: A relatively large number of whipsnakes passed through Prague Zoo in the 1950s, but these were transit animals. Visitors could first encounter them in the terrarium of the Indonesian Jungle pavilion, where the first female arrived in 2004. There was a brief breeding break from 2008–2011, but since then, we have not only kept them but also bred them successfully since 2011.
